information.section-title: Manage your productivity time with the Pomodoro Technique
information.info-title-1: What is the Pomodoro Technique?
information.info-text-1: The Pomodoro Technique is a popular time management system that involves working/studying in 25-minute intervals with short 5-minute breaks in between to maximize focus. This technique was developed by Francesco Cirillo in the late 1980s while he was a university student. He used a tomato-shaped timer from his kitchen to time himself. After repeated trial and error, tweaking the amount of time, he eventually put together the Pomodoro Technique.
information.info-title-2: How to use the Pomodoro Timer?
information.li-1-1: 1. List the tasks you want to accomplish in order of priority.
information.li-1-3: 3. Pick a task to work on.
information.li-1-4: 4. Start the timer and concentrate on the task until the time ends
information.li-1-6: 6. Take a longer break (15-30 minutes) after four pomodoros.
information.li-1-7: 7. Repeat the cycle until you complete all the tasks.
information.li-2-1: - Improves focus: This technique lets you break the habit of multitasking. It trains you to be able to focus on one task at a time with reasonable time intervals.
information.li-2-2: - Facilitates project planning: After getting used to doing pomodoros, you’ll be able to plan out tasks and projects with more precision.
information.li-2-3: - Decreases mental fatigue: A study found that doing prolonged tasks leads to a decrease in performance, while short breaks between tasks can help you keep the focus.
information.li-2-4: - Sustains motivation: Breaking down tasks and tackling them in short bursts, you’ll feel a sense of satisfaction seeing how much you can accomplish in 25 minutes.
